Key Match Events: England's build-up play has been shocking compared to City's
Trent Alexander-Arnold needs help from those around him to control the game
Kieran Trippier is being used as a left-back behind Foden, but his offensive characteristics are being nullified
Phil Foden is not being used to his full potential with England, as the pass to 'De Bruyne' is not being made
Jude Bellingham's role for England is not as defined as it is for Real Madrid
Eberechi Eze is not suited to being used wide left in a front three with little licence to come inside
Conor Gallagher is being used to provide energy and pressing for England
Pre-Game Insights: There is a disconnect between how England's players perform for their clubs and for the national team
Players are being asked to perform different roles for the national team from the ones they are used to with their clubs
England's build-up play has been shocking compared to City's
Post-Match Reflections: Gallagher may be outstanding at pressing, but if his team-mates do not match his application and intensity, England are unlikely to feel much benefit from his presence
Eze's most impactful performances come from starting games, and being a substitute relatively late on will do little for either Eze or England
Miscellaneous Highlights: England's passing network against Denmark has been compact, with players crowding each other's space
Trippier has yet to attempt or complete a cross in the tournament so far
Bellingham has not been used in his preferred role for England, which has resulted in confusion and a lack of space for him to operate
Others: England's team is fundamentally different to the one that won the 2022 World Cup, with a right-footer at left-back and a left winger who constantly drifts inside
Southgate wants Gallagher to provide energy and pressing for England, but he may not be a huge difference-maker
